metadata.case_name: Hanskumar Kishanchand v. Union of India

facts.text: Central Government requisitioned certain properties belonging to Hanskumar Kishanchand on February 19, 1941, under s.75A of the Rules framed under the Defence of India Act, 1939.
No agreement on compensation amount, referred to Mr. Jafry, Additional District Judge, Khandwa, under s.19(1)(b) of the Defence of India Act.
Mr. Jafry pronounced award on March 31, 1943, awarding Rs. 13,000 as annual rent for occupation of the premises.
Appeal to High Court of Nagpur under s.19(1)(f) of the Act, heard by Grille C.J. and Padhye J.
High Court judgment dated December 31, 1947, enhanced annual rent by Rs. 3,250 (to Rs. 16,250) and allowed compensation for dislocation of High School run on the property.
Appellant (Hanskumar) applied for leave to appeal to Federal Court under ss.109 and 110 CPC regarding amounts disallowed; Government applied regarding enhancement.
Leave granted on August 25, 1949, certificate issued that appeals fulfilled ss.109 and 110 CPC.
Preliminary objection by Solicitor-General to maintainability of Civil Appeal No. 224/54, arguing High Court judgment is an award, not judgment/decree/order under ss.109,110 CPC.

legal_issues.text: Whether the judgment of the High Court passed in appeal under s.19(1)(f) of the Defence of India Act, 1939, is a judgment, decree or order within ss.109 and 110 of the Code of Civil Procedure, making it appealable to the Supreme Court.
Whether the proceedings under s.19(1)(b) and appeal under s.19(1)(f) are arbitration proceedings, rendering the High Court decision an award not appealable under CPC.

petitioner_arguments.text: Proceedings under s.19(1)(b) are arbitration, but once matter comes before High Court by appeal under s.19(1)(f), it becomes a civil proceeding under ordinary jurisdiction of the Court, appealable under ss.109 and 110 CPC; alternatively, competent under Cl.29 Letters Patent.
Even if no appeal under CPC or Letters Patent, Supreme Court can grant leave under Federal Court Enlargement of Jurisdiction Act, 1948 s.3(a)(ii) devolving from Privy Council power under Art.135.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Federal Court (Enlargement of Jurisdiction) Act, 1948 s.3(a)(ii); Art.135 Constitution

respondent_arguments.text: Reference under s.19(1)(b) and appeal under s.19(1)(f) are arbitration proceedings; High Court decision is an award, not judgment/decree/order under ss.109,110 CPC; appeals incompetent.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Defence of India Act, 1939 s.19(1)(g); ss.109,110 CPC

court_reasoning.text: Arbitration proceedings withdraw lis from ordinary courts to private tribunal; award final unless set aside; distinction between court decision in ordinary jurisdiction (appealable) and as imprimatur on award (not appealable). Statutory arbitration same as consensual.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Reference to court as persona designata yields award, not appealable; as court, yields judgment.

court_reasoning.text: Under Defence of India Act s.19(1)(b), reference to arbitrator (qualified for High Court judge); s.19(1)(f) appeal to High Court as designated authority, not court; proceedings retain arbitration character; High Court decision is award.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Appeal under s.19(1)(f) continues arbitration; s.19(1)(g) excludes other laws.

court_reasoning.text: Distinguished National Telephone Co. (reference to court as court); followed Rangoon Botatoung, Salsette cases (arbitration appeals not judgments).
court_reasoning.key_observation: High Court in s.19(1)(f) appeal acts as arbitration tribunal.

court_reasoning.text: No power to grant special leave as decision not 'judgment' under s.2(b) Federal Court Act.

holdings.text: Decision of High Court in appeal under s.19(1)(f) Defence of India Act is not judgment/decree/order under ss.109,110 CPC or Cl.29 Letters Patent; it is an award in arbitration proceedings.
Appeals to Supreme Court incompetent; no special leave grantable.

precedents_cited.case_name: Rangoon Botatoung Company v. The Collector, Rangoon
precedents_cited.relevance: Decision in Land Acquisition appeal to court is award, not judgment appealable to Privy Council.

precedents_cited.case_name: The Special Officer, Salsette Building Sites v. Dossabhai Bezonji
precedents_cited.relevance: High Court appeal under Land Acquisition Act s.54 not judgment under Letters Patent Cl.39.

precedents_cited.case_name: The Special Officer, Salsette Building Sites v. Dassabhai Bozanji Motiwala
precedents_cited.relevance: Privy Council accepted Bombay HC view on non-appealability.

precedents_cited.case_name: Manavikraman Tirumalpad v. The Collector of the Nilgris
precedents_cited.relevance: High Court Land Acquisition appeal not judgment under Letters Patent Cl.15.

precedents_cited.case_name: Secretary of State for India in Council v. Hindusthan Co-operative Insurance Society Limited
precedents_cited.relevance: Calcutta Improvement Act appeal to High Court not further appealable to Privy Council.

precedents_cited.case_name: National Telephone Company Limited v. Postmaster-General
precedents_cited.relevance: Reference to established court imports ordinary procedure and appeal rights; unlike arbitration.

precedents_cited.case_name: Secretary of State for India v. Chelikani Rama Rao
precedents_cited.relevance: Distinction: Forest Act reference to District Court as court (appealable); Land Acquisition as arbitrator (not).

precedents_cited.case_name: Kollegal Silk Filatures Ltd. v. Province of Madras
precedents_cited.relevance: s.19(1)(g) covers entire proceedings including High Court appeal as arbitration.

statutes_cited.name: Defence of India Act, 1939
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs requisition compensation determination by arbitrator and appeal to High Court as arbitration.

statutes_cited.name: Land Acquisition Act, 1894
statutes_cited.relevance: Arbitrator to have regard to its provisions for compensation.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Civil Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: Appealability of judgments/decrees/orders; High Court decision not within.

statutes_cited.name: Arbitration Act, 1940
statutes_cited.relevance: Applies to statutory arbitrations; awards not appealable except limited grounds.

statutes_cited.name: Federal Court (Enlargement of Jurisdiction) Act, 1948
statutes_cited.relevance: Special leave only against 'judgment' (decree/order); not applicable to award.

outcome.summary: Both appeals dismissed as incompetent because the High Court judgment under s.19(1)(f) of the Defence of India Act is an award in arbitration proceedings, not a judgment/decree/order appealable under ss.109 and 110 CPC or Letters Patent.

key_quotes.text: Their Lordships cannot accept the argument or suggestion that when once the claimant is admitted to the High Court he has all the rights of an ordinary suitor, including the right to carry an award made in an arbitration as to the value of land taken for public purposes up to this Board as if it were a decree of the High Court made in the course of its ordinary jurisdiction.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: From Rangoon Botatoung; core principle rejecting appeal from arbitration awards.

key_quotes.text: When a question is stated to be referred to an established Court without more, it, in my opinion, imports that the ordinary incidents of the procedure of that Court are to attach, and also that any general right of appeal from its decision likewise attaches.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: From National Telephone; distinguishes court vs. persona designata references.

key_quotes.text: In our view, a proceeding which is at the inception an arbitration proceeding must retain its character as arbitration, even when it is taken up in appeal, where that is provided by the statute.
key_quotes.key_observation: Court's holding on continuity of arbitration nature.
